prior_works.title: Anchor Graph Regularization for Large-Scale Semi-Supervised Learning
prior_works.authors: Wei Liu, Junfeng He, Shih-Fu Chang
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SIIHPC’s step that transforms partial bipartition (sample–prototype) information back into an original sample–sample similarity leverages the anchor-graph reconstruction idea of building dense affinities from a bipartite representation.

prior_works.title: Similarity Learning via Self-Representation
prior_works.authors: Feiping Nie, Xiaoqian Wang, Heng Huang
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s move to relax traditional nonnegative constraints and learn similarities through reconstruction is directly inspired by self-representation–based similarity learning that regularizes reconstruction coefficients instead of enforcing strict nonnegativity.

prior_works.title: Auto-Weighted Multiple Graph Learning: A Unified Framework for Multi-View Clustering
prior_works.authors: Feiping Nie, Jing Li, Xuelong Li
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SIIHPC recovers missing similarities by tying view-exclusive graphs to a shared consensus graph, a strategy rooted in auto-weighted multi-graph learning that fuses per-view structures into a common consensus topology.

prior_works.title: Partial Multi-View Clustering
prior_works.authors: Xiaochun Cao, Changqing Zhang, Huazhu Fu, Si Liu
prior_works.role: Early IMVC baseline that ignores missing views
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By highlighting the limitation of exploiting only observed samples in partial-view settings, this work motivates SIIHPC’s similarity-level imputation rather than discarding missing portions.

prior_works.title: Doubly Aligned Incomplete Multi-View Clustering (DAIMC)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SIIHPC departs from DAIMC-like single shared prototype/indicator assumptions by introducing hybrid prototype groups per view to better capture heterogeneous view structures.

prior_works.title: One-Pass Incomplete Multi-View Clustering (OPIMC)
prior_works.role: Prototype-based IMVC with bipartite modeling of incomplete data
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper generalizes the prototype-centric, bipartite formulation in OPIMC by reconstructing a sample-level similarity from partial bipartite links and extending to flexible, per-view hybrid prototypes for richer representation.

synthesis_narrative:
SIIHPC’s core advances—similarity-level imputation tied to a cross-view consensus graph and intra-view hybrid-group prototypes—sit at the intersection of bipartite reconstruction, self-representation similarity learning, and multi-graph consensus principles. Anchor Graph Regularization established the practice of deriving dense sample–sample affinities from a compact bipartite representation, a blueprint SIIHPC uses to convert partial bipartition signals (due to missing views) back into a standard similarity graph. Complementing this, self-representation–based similarity learning showed that high-quality graphs can be learned via reconstruction with appropriate regularization rather than strict nonnegativity, motivating SIIHPC’s relaxation of nonnegative constraints to better fit real data geometry.

On the multi-view side, AMGL formalized learning a consensus structure from multiple view-specific graphs, directly informing SIIHPC’s mechanism that imputes missing similarities by coupling each view’s exclusive similarity to a shared consensus graph. Classic IMVC methods such as PVC, DAIMC, and OPIMC exposed two key limitations SIIHPC addresses: (i) they often ignore missing samples or rely only on observed pairs, and (ii) they typically enforce a single shared set of prototypes/cluster indicators across all views. SIIHPC remedies (i) by operating at the similarity level to recover unobserved relations via consensus-guided imputation, and tackles (ii) by introducing hybrid prototype groups within each view, enabling flexible, view-specific representation capacity while still aligning through a learned consensus graph. Together, these strands yield a simple yet effective IMVC pipeline that unifies reconstruction-driven graph learning with principled cross-view consensus and richer per-view prototyping.
